section-block.rac_essential-question: What can we learn from using our senses?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Victoria Pérez Escrivá and illustrated by Claudia Renucci.
section-block.rac_book_summary: One brother cannot see. One brother can see. In this story, the brother who cannot see teaches his brother new ways to “see” the world. What will he teach everyone?

section-block.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Use Kk and Ll Alphabet Cards.
section-block.rac_teacher-talk_blue: K is for kite. I spy a kite. Who can show me what I spy? Continue for both sides of the cards.

section-block.rac_body-text: Ask children to point to their eyes. What do they help you do? Continue with ears, nose, hands, and tongue. Help children conclude that these parts help them learn.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Close Your Eyes, written by Victoria Pérez Escrivá and illustrated by Claudia Ranucci.

Pablo loves reading about children. This narrative, or story, is about two brothers—one who can see and one who cannot see. The brother who cannot see uses his ears to hear, his nose to smell, and his hands to touch things.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What things do the brothers argue about?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: One brother says that when he tries to explain things, his brother argues with him. What is the first thing they argue about?
What do the brothers argue about now?
What sound does the letter l make in legs?
This word has a lowercase k. What sound does the letter k make in snake?
What do the brothers argue about now? Give a thumbs up if you think a bar of soap smells good.
How might closing his eyes help the brother who can see understand what it’s like for the brother who cannot see?
Let’s turn and talk about the Guiding Question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What things do the brothers argue about?
section.rac_body-text: Give time for Turn and Talk.
Then, use Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to share their ideas.
Possible responses:
Write and read aloud short sentences about the things children notice with their senses.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do the brothers argue about soap?
What other things do you think they argue about?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Learning the letters of the alphabet is a prerequisite to eventually learning to read and write. The rate at which children learn their ABCs varies, but exposure to print is key. To encourage letter recognition, point out and name letters in the room around you and label children’s desks and cubbies with names.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Focus Attention
section-block.rac_body-text: Remind children that they can focus their attention on something and try not to get distracted. Show children the picture sides of Alphabet Cards from Aa to Ll. Hold each card up for a second, and then ask: Were you paying attention? What did you see? After using the cards, ask children to tell what, if anything distracted them and caused them to look away.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to think about the Focus Attention Mind Builder. As we revisit Close Your Eyes by Victoria Pérez Escrivá, let’s pay attention to what each brother says.
Clifford loves this book because it shows how two children describe things in different ways.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 2 prompts. Use the Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s pay attention. One brother explains that a tree is a big stick that comes out of the earth. Which part of the tree do you think he was touching when he said that? (MB)
Let’s pay attention to what he says now. He says that a snake is a cold, smooth rope. Which part of the snake do you think he was touching when he said that? (MB)
Let’s think about what he says now. He says that a heart-shaped clock is a little box with a heart inside. What do you think he was hearing when he said that? (MB)
One brother says the moon is a whole bunch of crickets. Close your eyes and imagine you hear a whole bunch of crickets. Is it noisy or quiet?

section.rac_body-text: Play “What’s Missing?” Invite children to sit in a circle. Present five objects, such as a crayon, scissors, ruler, chalk, and marker. Name each one as you place it in the circle. Ask children to close and hide their eyes. Remove one item and hide it. Have children open their eyes and ask, “What’s missing?” Return the item and repeat, removing a different item each time. Gradually add additional items to engage children’s visual memory and engage their ability to pay attention. (MB)
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about what things they use their ears to hear. [Note: revise for children with auditory impairments.]

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Focusing one’s attention is a basic executive function skill that children need to develop in order to begin learning. Children must work through several steps to successfully pay attention: 1) be alert, 2) select what to pay attention to and sustain that attention even with outside distractions, and 3) if distracted, shift focus back to task. (Rosen/Understood.org)

section-block.rac_body-text: Guide children to understand that one brother in Close Your Eyes is blind. How does he use his ears, nose, and hands to help him learn about things?
Tune: “Farmer in the Dell”“I use my eyes to see, I use my eyes to see, And when I want to see a star, I use my eyes to see.” (ears/hear; nose/smell; hands/touch)

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book Close Your Eyes by Victoria Pérez Escrivá.
Pablo likes this narrative about using our senses in different ways.
This is the guiding question I want you to think about as we read:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How can you learn about something?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: One brother sees the tree and tells about it. The other brother touches the tree and tells about. Close your eyes. Pretend you are touching a tree. How does it feel?
One brother sees the clock and tells about it. The other brother listens to the clock and tells about it. Close your eyes. Pretend you are listening to a clock. What do you hear?
One brother sees soap and tells about it. The other brother feels the soap and smells it. Close your eyes. Pretend you are holding a bar of soap. How does it feel?
The brother who can see has a problem. Why is it a good idea for the boy to share his problem with their mother?
section.rac_body-text: Explain to children that it’s good to try to solve a problem by themselves, but if they can’t, it’s good to ask a grown-up for help.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How can you learn about something?
section.rac_body-text: Give time for Turn and Talk.
Then, use Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to share.
Possible responses:
Share a pen with children as you work together to talk and write about things they use their noses to smell.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What senses are good to learn about soap?
I can see, touch, and sm____ (smell) soap.
I can see, touch, and smell soap.
What is something else you can see, touch, and smell?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: One effective strategy in supporting multilingual learners is family engagement. Meet with parents to discuss children’s exposure to both their home language and English. Determine ways to include cultural influences into activities. If possible, include both English and children’s home language on classroom labels, and displays.

section-block.rac_body-text: Engage children in learning about senses. Sing the following to the tune of The Muffin Man. “Oh, do you hear the clock tick-tock, the clock tick-tock, the clock tick-tock? Oh, do you hear the clock tick-tock? That’s how it sounds to me.” Continue with “Do you smell the yummy treat—that’s how it smells to me; do you feel the squishy dough—that’s how it feels to me.”
Introduce new words that will help you talk about senses.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read See! Hear! Taste! Smell! and Touch! This poster tells how we can use each of our senses.
Pablo enjoys looking at informational posters that tell about the senses.
Close Your Eyes and See! Hear! Taste! Smell! and Touch! both tell about how we use our senses. Let’s see how the texts are alike.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show Close Your Eyes book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about the concept question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What can we learn from using our senses?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Five Senses
section.rac_body-text: Share the poster. Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart. Then, use these prompts to read and discuss the poster together.
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: What can I use my eyes to see?
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do you use your eyes to see when you’re at school? Outside?
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: What can I use my nose to smell?
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Touch your nose when I say something you like to smell: soap, flowers, soup, pizza, or popcorn.
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: What can I use my ears to hear?
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Touch your ears when I say something you like to hear: drums beating, a story, horns honking, singing, or thunder.
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: What can I use my tongue to taste?
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can show me how you look when you taste something yummy? Yucky? Spicy?
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: What can I use my hands to touch?
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do you like to touch soft things? Rough things? Bumpy things?
What things did the brother who cannot see touch?
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show Close Your Eyes book cover.

section.rac_body-text: Gather items that children can identify using their senses (a bumpy sensory ball, soft scarf, bell, flower with a strong scent, half a sticky marshmallow, keys, cinnamon stick, cotton balls, sandpaper, and tambourine). Have children pull one item at a time from a bag. Can you see it? Smell it? Hear it? Touch it? Help children keep their attention. (MB)
Provide a writing prompt about things we can touch. Give support as children draw and write.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children naturally explore their world through “sensory play.” Providing opportunities for children to actively engage their senses helps build nerve connections in the brain. These connections are crucial in strengthening children’s abilities to process and respond to sensory stimulation. Note that our skin is used for touching.

section-block.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Say: We have been learning about the five senses. Let’s take a few minutes to celebrate with some dancing! Everyone gets a scarf. Use your sense of hearing to start. Use your sense of touch to wave your scarf and move it fast or slow as you dance to music. When the music stops, freeze. Listen for the new beat and start dancing again. Use your sense of sight to watch out for your friends.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and act out the book Close Your Eyes by Victoria Pérez Escrivá.
Pablo loves this book. Thinking about our senses makes him feel like a scientist!
This week, we read about two brothers. We found out that the brother who could not see used his other senses. He could hear, touch, and smell things.
Now, I want you to think about this Guiding Question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How do our senses help us learn?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: You can see a snake slither. Use your arm and show me how a snake slithers.

We can listen to a clock tick tock. What sound do you hear at the beginning of the word listen? What letter make the /l/ sound? What sound do you hear at the end of ticktock? What letter makes the /k/sound?
Let’s all make the sound of a clock tick-tocking.
You can touch and smell soap. Let’s pretend we have a bar of soap. Let’s wet it and make lather. Let’s wash our hands and dry them. Finally, let’s smell our hands to see how good they smell.
Close your eyes. Pretend you’re falling asleep. You can hear crickets singing. Let’s chirp like the crickets in the night. Now whisper to a friend and say, “Good night!”
What does his mother tell the brother to do? Now close your eyes. Listen! What do you hear?

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk for a moment about the Guiding Question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How do our senses help us learn?
section.rac_body-text: Give time for Turn and Talk.
Then, use the Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to share their responses.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Our hands let us touch things.
Our noses let us smell things.
Our eyes let us see how things look.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about how they use one of their senses.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does your nose help you smell things?
My nose helps me sm_____ (smell) things.
My nose helps me smell things.
What senses have you used today?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Gross motor skills are important to children’s physical development. Activities, such as scarf dancing, that require large muscle movement help build these skills in children. Gross motor abilities impact children’s success in school and in participating in everyday functions, such as sitting upright, writing and drawing, and playing sports.
